basics.name: Zhuoya Shi
basics.label: Ph.D.
basics.summary: Experienced Data Scientist with a background in civil engineering, specializing in data analysis, modeling techniques, and digital transformation. Proven ability to collaborate with industry partners to develop innovative solutions for data collection and visualization.

work.name: New York University
work.summary: Research focusing on improving current building façade maintenance processes. Participated in quantification of architecture impact on humans in the built environment.
highlights: Conducted interviews with façade consulting experts from ten companies and NYC DOB group to identify key challenges.
Analyzed 2500+ reports using machine learning models, achieving 93% accuracy in identifying critical information.
Identified defect patterns in NYC neighborhoods by implementing spatial clustering analysis for buildings
Developed an object-oriented representation schema and reasoning mechanisms to generate customized checklists,improving 33% efficiency
Conducted hypothesis testing for 356 responses, identifying nine impactful architectural design features.

work.name: Desimone Consulting Engineers
work.summary: Spearheaded digital practices for façade inspection.
highlights: Led initiatives for effective digital practice for façade inspection utilizing BIM and associated technology.
Initiated effective digital practices, designing a database for reports management, achieving an 11% reporting time saving.
Coordinated project meetings with four stakeholder companies, ensuring timely survey report submissions.

work.name: University of Southern California
highlights: Prepared 2D CAD drawings for proactive scan planning of existing buildings.
Processed and analyzed point cloud data using Autodesk Recap and CloudCompare.

education.institution: New York University, New York, NY
University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA
courses: Building Information Modeling and Integrated Practice

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'
